\abstract{
We study two extensions to the Jaynes Cummings model described by  Markovian master equations with Lindblad 
operators causing either dephasing or photon losses solely involving the cavity mode.  
We treat the two-level atom as the central system under investigation, 
while the mode of the cavity plays the role of a near environment coupled 
via the Lindblad operators to an imagined far environment. 
We show that increasing the dephasing or damping parameter of the cavity
systematically slows the decoherence of the atom.
The exact solvability allows us to determine the relation to the quantum 
Zeno effect and the perturbative regime. 
}

\section{Introduction}
The loss of coherence in quantum systems is one of the major obstacles to overcome 
in order to achieve effective quantum communication technologies and 
quantum computation implementations \cite{Nielsen}. 
The main source of decoherence is the 
environment to which the system under investigation couples invariably. 
Recently there has been a surge of interest in using the coherence loss of the ``near'' 
environment of a central quantum system to stabilize the coherence of the latter. 
This reaches from the limit of very fast decoherence of the near environment \cite{Zanardi}, 
which may actually lead in some limit to a protected subspace for the central system,
all the way to perturbative treatments where all couplings are small
\cite{MGS, GMS}. Numerical results for spin systems \cite{Gonzalez} and random matrix 
environments \cite{MGS} seem to support such improvement through the range of coupling strength. 
In all cases there seems to exist options to improve coherence  of the central system 
considerably if it is already quite good to start with. 
Indeed it so seems, that weak coupling of the central system to the near environment 
is the only prerequisite for this method to be workable. 
It provides a practical alternative to dynamical decoupling or topologically protected 
decoherence free subspaces and other methods to extend coherence times.




The purpose of this work is to investigate this problem in two paradigmatic, simple, 
and exactly solvable 
 models in quantum optics: A Jaynes-Cummings model with dephasing and 
 a damped Jaynes-Cummings model. Thereby, the dephasing and the damping mechanisms are
 assumed to act solely on the cavity mode.
The role of central system is played by a two-level atom which 
is coupled to a single mode of an optical cavity acting as the near environment.
Decoherence of the cavity is taken into account to mimic the effects
of a far environment. We assume that the two types of decoherence mechanisms in the cavity which
can be described in terms of a Markovian master equation in 
Gorini-Kossakowski-Sudarshan-Lindblad form \cite{Gorini,Lindblad}.
In a first approach we consider a dephasing model, with the number operator as Lindblad
operator. This may not be very realistic, but it will turn out to be most illustrative
due to its simple analytical treatment and the absence of competing effects: The  Liouville operator can be expressed in terms of disconnected
$4\times 4$ matrices. 
In a second case, photon losses are considered by choosing the annihilation operator
as Lindblad operator. This case can be connected to the standard setting in the 
Haroche experiment \cite{Haroche}. 
For both cases, we have worked out analytical expressions of the reduced density matrix
of the atom and its purity to measure the decoherence of the central system.
We find that in the strong coupling
limit of the cavity to the outside world, the atomic state 
remains pure, i.e., it evolves coherently in time. 
For the damping case  we find this to be an 
excellent illustration for the improved conservation of Energy in the qubit which is in 
line with known  results \cite{Nemes}.
The simple fact that we do get exact solutions in a special but non trivial case 
of a rather complicated system
is of great interest, as it will allow us to gain insight in possible mechanisms of 
behaviours encountered.
It may be noted that a number of special cases of
this system as well as particular situations in similar systems have been
studied. We shall return to some of these cases during the discussion.
We shall start by briefly defining the model and then proceed to discuss the
simpler case, where the Lindblad operator is the number operator of the
harmonic mode (which can be interpreted as dephasing of the oscillator); 
this we will do, despite of the fact that it is less realistic than a
loss term, because it is very transparent. 
Next we will address the case of photon losses in the cavity in which the annihilation
operator of the oscillator is considered as Lindblad operator.
Finally we shall discuss to what extent our considerations may shed light 
into known numerical and random matrix results \cite{MGS,GMS,Gonzalez},
and discuss in what ways the basic result can be used to help control coherence.

\section{Conclusions}
With the dephasing Lindblad operator we have a very simple example, 
where we can see the entire developement of decoherence as a function of time 
for different parameters. The scaling behaviour is readily established and we see, 
that  the same equation describes the improvement of decoherence from 
the perturbative all the way to the strong coupling regime, as could be hoped from the 
rather general analytic results implicit in references \cite{Zanardi} and \cite{MGS, GMS}. 
Yet in the perturbative regime for $\kappa$ it seemed that for chaotic environments in the 
Fermi golden rule regime, i.e. with exponential coherence decay the effect of the far 
environment was no longer noticeable. The latter effect is not seen in our system. 
For the case of loss we will have perfect return to a pure state both if the loss sends the
central system to the ground state and if a Zeno effect preserves the excitation of the 
oscillator and thus makes it impossible for this system to absorb energy from the central 
system. We thus see, that while the same equation governs the system, the qualitative explanation 
using the quantum Zeno effect will only describe the strong coupling limit, as for weak 
coupling we have complete decoherence and later recoherence while there is a transition to another state. 
This is manifested in the purity as an oscillatory behaviour that precludes the interpretation as a quantum 
Zeno effect; this is in agreement with the findings of \cite{MGS}. 
There the protection of coherence by decoherence of the environment was shown in a weak coupling 
regime by linear response considerations, which also preclude a quantum Zeno effect.
Thus our two simple models go a long way in explaining what is going on in the matter 
of decoherence of a near environment protecting the central system. Yet, as is to be expected 
some aspects of more realistic systems are not covered by the model behaviour.
